articles.title: Hundreds of birds struck against buildings this fall
articles.author: David Yin
articles.summary: Fatal Light Awareness Program (FLAP) Canada's Global Bird Collision Mapper users recorded over 775 birds struck by buildings in Markham since August. This is hundreds more than Richmond Hill, Vaughan, and Scarborough combined.   -

articles.title: Honduras: Climate Change Advances Quicker than Gov. Policies
articles.author: Circles Robinson
articles.summary: Honduras is one of the world's most vulnerable countries to climate change, according to Germanwatch's Climate Risk Index 2025. Honduras has presented a second update of its nationally determined contribution (NDC) to the 30th Conference of the Parties (COP30) on climate change. The NDC outlines the country's climate action plan, including its target for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. It's an action provided for in the Paris Agreement, in which nations commit to curbing global warming through promises to reduce emissions, restore forests, and advance towards resilient development. Experts warn that the ambitious targets Honduras presents in its NDC do not seem realistic.

articles.title: Officials race to save beloved US island from looming crisis — here's what's happening
articles.author: Geri Mileva
articles.summary: Rising tides are closing in on Sullivan's Island in South Carolina. Town leaders are working on a long-term flood mitigation plan. The plan lays out strategies to safeguard the island's resources, restore natural systems, and protect the community from flooding, erosion and high tides.

articles.title: In protected forests of Karnataka, human-animal conflict brews on the fringe
articles.author: Pavan Kumar H
articles.summary: Changes in human behaviour, dwindling forest cover and habitat fragmentation have intensified human-animal conflicts, experts say.   Â. Â   y  y   i   in the world of humans and animals is increasing conflicts between them.

articles.title: Liberals risk joining 'baddies' with fossil-fuel push
articles.author: The West Australian
articles.summary: Australia cannot pull out of the Paris Agreement, a Liberal frontbencher has declared. His party is preparing to face off over climate and energy policy.       "Australia can't withdraw from Paris Agreement," a Liberal Frontbencher declared.

articles.title: The ocean is building up a massive burp
articles.author: Matt Simon
articles.summary: Since the Industrial Revolution, humans have been adding a lot of CO2 to the atmosphere. The Southern Ocean holds 80% of the world's heat. New modeling suggests that the Southern Ocean will start to emit CO2 again if humans don't reduce their CO2 emissions.

articles.title: NEWBURY: Much new under the sun
articles.summary: Their numbers are dwindling. People are spending too much time in the shade or staring at the sun, which doesn't seem to be a problem for them at least so far, though. They are still alive and well, as far as I can tell.

articles.title: Tame Lake Naivasha flooding
articles.author: Editorial
articles.summary: Flooding of Lake Naivasha has put the tourism industry at serious risk for visitors and hotel workers. Some 4,000 families have been displaced and infrastructure destroyed due to the floods. Climate change has increased the amount of water flowing into the lakes with adverse consequences.

articles.title: Rising sea leaves villagers homeless on Kakinada coast
articles.author: Jinnala Umamaheswara Rao
articles.summary: Uppada, a coastal panchayat near Kakinada, is home to several fishing villages now facing existential threat from rising sea levels and extreme weather events. Nearly 1,360 acres of private land have been lost to erosion, a crisis worsened by Cyclone Montha. A seawall project prepared by the National Centre for Coastal Research (NCCR) is awaiting final approval from the Union government.

articles.title: Climate vulnerability
articles.author: editorial
articles.summary: The world warns Pakistan about climate risks while offering little beyond frameworks, advice and debt-linked facilities. Pakistan is pushed to integrate climate considerations into its public financial management in a context where genuine international support has been chronically delayed or quietly diluted. The Loss and Damage Fund, celebrated as a historic breakthrough, remains symbolic for frontline states. Adaptation financing comes slowly and mostly as loans that strain already limited fiscal space.

articles.title: 'We can't accept this': no time for climate COP out
articles.summary: Global climate talks are taking place in the Amazon. Political headwinds threaten to blow multinational collaboration off course, says the UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon. The talks will continue in the next few days, he adds. The UN Secretary General is expected to attend.

articles.title: West Green residents decry slow water restoration after Hurricane Melissa
articles.author: Jamaica Observer
articles.summary: Residents in West Green, St James, complain about the slow response in restoring water to the community over a week after Hurricane Melissa struck. Observer Online visited the community on Thursday and residents were searching through soiled clothes and rubble to find water-damaged items.

articles.title: Marissa Bode's Comment About Standing Up to ‘Power-Hungry Dictator' Cut From ‘Wicked' NBC Special
articles.author: Dan Clarendon
articles.summary: Griffin, GA (30223) has mixed clouds and sunshine today. A stray shower or thunderstorm is possible. High 76F. Winds SW at 5 to 10 mph. Tonight some clouds are possible, with a few showers or thunderstorms, mainly in the evening.

articles.title: Granite Island little penguin numbers on the up
articles.author: Hui Jin
articles.summary: This year's Granite Island little penguin census has shown that not only are numbers increasing, but the birds are in good health. Dani Brown is the author of the census report.   .    i   for this census report, click here to see it.

articles.title: Climate threats could cost Alaska billions. After October's storm, advocates say it's time to act.
articles.author: Alaska Beacon
articles.summary: After October's storm, advocates say it's time to act on climate change. Alaska is at risk of losing billions of dollars due to climate change-related disasters.      Â   .   y   in Alaska.

articles.title: Three tracks to rescue 1.5°C: fossil exit, forest protection, and nature's carbon (commentary)
articles.author: Mongabay
articles.summary: The last year's global temperature averaged more than 1.5°C above pre-industrial levels, shredding the margin for error under the Paris Agreement. It doesn't doom the goal forever, but it leaves a lot of room for error for the future.

articles.title: Living on Borrowed Time
articles.summary: Pakistan's economy is at the mercy of climate shocks. The policy response is piecemeal, reactive and cosmetic. Pakistan's survival hinges on treating climate adaptation as an existential priority. Urban planning must acknowledge that unchecked sprawl and deforestation are not signs of development but of decline. Governance reform is indispensable.

articles.title: Louisiana Commission Proposes Buffer Zone Changes for Menhaden Fishery Along Coastal Regions
articles.author: Jackie Ramirez-Lopez
articles.summary: Louisiana Wildlife and Fisheries Commission has proposed changes to buffer zones surrounding the state's commercial menhaden fishery. The proposed changes will shrink certain buffer zones from ½ mile to ¼ mile and introduce a gap between Baptiste Collette and Breton Island. Citizens are invited to submit comments on the proposed rule until January 23, 2026.

articles.title: The UN assesses damage in eastern Cuba following the passage of Melissa
articles.author: Ciber Cuba Editorial Team
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa caused severe damage in the province of Holguín and nearby municipalities. UNICEF Cuba sent medical supplies to the most affected areas. UN wants to raise $74.2 million to assist one million people affected by the storm.    The UN described Hurricane Melissa as one of the most intense hurricanes ever recorded in the Atlantic, the Caribbean and the Gulf of Mexico.

articles.title: MEDIA ADVISORY - Minister Diab to Highlight Federal Budget Investments in Climate
articles.author: CNW Group
articles.summary: The Honourable Lena Metlege Diab, Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship, will host an event in Halifax, to make a Budget 2025 climate competitiveness announcement. Minister Diab will be joined by Shannon Miedema, Member of Parliament for Halifax. Media are asked to register in advance for this in-person event by sharing their name, title, email address and outlet with IRCC@cic.ca by Sunday, November 9, at 12 p.m. AT.

articles.title: Minister Diab to Highlight Federal Budget Investments in Climate
articles.author: Dayang Norazhar
articles.summary: The Minister of Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship, Lena Metlege Diab, will host an event in Halifax to make a Budget 2025 climate competitiveness announcement. Minister Diab will be joined by Shannon Miedema, Member of Parliament for Halifax. Media are asked to register in advance for this in-person event by sharing their name, title, email address and outlet with IRCC.Info-Info.IRCC@cic.ca by Sunday, November 9, at 12 p.m.

articles.title: Loss and damage finance must reach frontline communities
articles.author: Data Analyst
articles.summary: COP30 is taking place in Belém, Brazil on November 10th. African negotiators, civil society organisations, and climate experts want the Loss and Damage agenda to move from symbolic pledges to actual funding reaching affected communities on the ground. The AGN is pushing for predictable, grant-based finance, not loans that increase debt burdens on already struggling economies. The Africa Group insists the Fund must be fully operational, fairly governed, and deliver timely support to vulnerable countries. The Pan African Climate Justice Alliance wants COP30 to adopt a justice-centred approach.

articles.title: Typhoon Fung-Wong forecast to move unusually, unlikely to affect Vietnam
articles.author: The World
articles.summary: Typhoon Fung-Wong is churning across the waters near the Philippines. It is projected to enter the East Sea on November 10. Vietnam should stay alert for indirect effects, especially on the sea, coastlines and weather in offshore zones. Deputy Minister of Agriculture and Environment signed an official dispatch to five ministries in charge of public security, national defence, construction and foreign affairs.

articles.title: Less Than 1% Of Climate Funding Allocated For Health Systems Since 2004: Report
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: This underinvestment comes as climate change is projected to cause up to 15.6 million deaths by 2050 due to factors like extreme heat, the spread of infectious diseases, and infrastructure failure, according to the UNFCCC. The UNFCC is concerned about underinvesting in climate change adaptation.

articles.title: Typhoon Uwan Threat: Signal No. 4 Raised Over Catanduanes, Northern Luzon Set for 'Catastrophic Destruction'
articles.author: Jaja Agpalo
articles.summary: Typhoon Uwan has rapidly intensified, forcing authorities to raise the danger level to Signal No. 4. The entire country is bracing for a potentially catastrophic mix of typhoon-force winds, high seas up to 14.0 metres, and life-threatening storm surges exceeding 3.0 m within the next 48 hours. The situation demands immediate public compliance with evacuation orders and disaster protocols.

articles.title: UN Denounces Failure to Limit Global Warming at COP30
articles.author: Colombia One
articles.summary: António Guterres warns that the planet has failed to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius since the creation of the Paris Agreement. COP30 will be held in Brazil, which will be attended by heads of state, ministers and heads of government.

articles.title: Units of Survival: We're On Our Own
articles.author: Sninky Poo
articles.summary: David Suzuki thinks the fight against climate change is lost, but many voices still ring out with hopeful messages. According to NASA, if we stopped emitting greenhouse gases today, the rise in global temperatures would begin to flatten within a few years. The benefits of reduced greenhouse gas emissions occur on the same timescale as the political decisions that lead to reductions.

articles.title: Water temperatures in Amazonian lakes rise to unprecedented levels, killing wildlife
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Temperatures in some Amazonian lakes reached 41 degrees Celsius (105.8 degrees Fahrenheit) during a drought and heat wave in 2023. The observations highlight the major threats that will likely affect the people and biodiversity of the Amazon and other tropical waters in the years to come.

articles.title: Less Than 1% Of Climate Funding Allocated For Health Systems Since 2004: Report
articles.author: Shreya Ghosh
articles.summary: The report by Adelphi, a think tank focusing on climate and environment, shows that despite widespread acknowledgement that climate finance is health finance, only 0.5% of multilateral climate funding has been channelled toward adapting health systems to a changing climate since 2004. Climate change is projected to cause up to 15.6 million deaths by 2050 due to factors like extreme heat, the spread of infectious diseases, and infrastructure failure. The funding crisis casts a long shadow over vulnerable nations, including those in South Asia like India. New Delhi's success in driving large-scale welfare programmes with climate co-benefits shows a blueprint for action.

articles.title: Church on seashore near Thoothukudi may submerge due to erosion
articles.author: P. Sudhakar
articles.summary: The 23-year-old church on Tharuvaikulam beach is about to be washed away by the rapidly advancing sea. The church, dedicated to St. Santhiyagappar (St. James), was built on the seashore about 750 meters away from the shoreline. The sea erosion has already swallowed nearby fishnet mending hall. The fishermen are appealing to the Department of Fisheries to construct a groyne to stop the sea erosion.

articles.title: Where do we go from here?: See how climate change is changing where we live
articles.author: Hindustan Times
articles.summary: Climate change is not a distant threat. People are being rendered homeless or jobless because of it, and they are moving due to it. A wildfire in Palaia Fokaia, south of Athens in Greece in August 2025 will be the worst case scenario.

articles.title: Andrea Borsvold: Thankful for sweater weather
articles.author: Coffee
articles.summary: Andrea Borsvold is a busy homesteading mama of three living in northwestern Minnesota. She writes regular columns for the Grand Forks Herald. Andrea is rekindling her love for simple sweaters, from crewnecks and hoodies on casual days to woven sweaters and button-down cardigans for more formal affairs.

articles.title: Where do we go from here?: See how humans are moving, amid climate change
articles.summary: Alice Baillat is a policy advisor with the Geneva-based Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre (IDMC), one of the world's leading data sources on displacement. According to the latest GRID report, there were 46 million displacements due to natural disasters in 2024 alone. Most people who lose their homes or livelihoods to a natural disaster move from one part to another.

articles.title: At The Climate Crossroads: Oil platform goes green to boost production
articles.author: Transcript
articles.summary: "On this deck, the debate doesn't matter – only the data does" says the content of the deck. The data is from the Convergence data-url:https://ui.cgtn.com/convergence/v4/content/conversation/v3.

articles.title: UWI Scientists Co-Author Study That Finds Climate Change Enhanced Hurricane Melissa's Intensity
articles.author: Editor
articles.summary: Scientists from The University of the West Indies (UWI) have contributed to a rapid analysis of Hurricane Melissa. The study confirms that human-induced climate change made the storm more intense and destructive. It also shows that the maximum rainfall over five days in Jamaica and eastern Cuba is now between 20 and 50 per cent higher than in pre-industrial times.

articles.title: Nation's migratory birds increasingly considering just not coming back, study shows
articles.author: simonjjames
articles.summary: 72% of the Nation's migratory birds consider not coming back or staying abroad. Dr Gerald Brearly spoke to over 3000 birds over the last 2 years. Newsbiscuit travelled to Lesotho to interview Jonathan and his wife Karen, British Migratory Swallows.

articles.title: 2025 ‘almost certain' to be one of the three hottest years on record
articles.author: Philenews
articles.summary: The year 2025 is almost certain to rank as one of the three hottest years on record, according to an analysis released Thursday by the Copernicus Climate Change Service. The forecast follows the global temperature analysis for October, which was the warmest month on record.

articles.title: Today's Top 3 News: As COP30 Opens, Indonesian Civil Institutions Calls for Clear Direction on Climate Funding
articles.author: Tempo.co
articles.summary: Indonesian Civil Institutions calls for clear direction on climate funding as COP30 opens. A Colorado State University study reveals the threat posed by climate change to plantation crops such as coffee, chocolate, and wine. Warren Buffett's portfolio continues to display remarkable resilience and momentum.

articles.title: Mental health in a warming world: why this is a looming crisis
articles.author: The Hindu
articles.summary: Farmers, coastal and coastal areas are the least responsible for emissions of climate change. They are responsible for most of the greenhouse gasses. They should be held responsible for climate change, not others.       .   for their actions.

articles.title: Mental health in a warming world: why this is a looming crisis
articles.author: Sudheer Kumar Shukla
articles.summary: Climate change is a catalyst for psychological distress in the Global South, home to a majority of the world's climate-exposed populations and the least-equipped health systems. In 2024, South Asia alone witnessed 9.2 million internal displacements due to climate change. Global survey of young people aged 16–25 found that 59% were worried about climate change and 45% reported negative impacts on daily functioning.

articles.title: OCD: 'Exposed' PH population to Typhoon Uwan at 30.8 million
articles.author: Ted Cordero
articles.summary: Typhoon Uwan is expected to make landfall over Isabela or northern section of Aurora on Sunday evening or Monday early morning. The total population of provinces exposed to Uwan's storm surge is 30.8 million. About 1.6 million people are in coastal areas exposed to the storm surge. 8.4 million Filipinos may be affected.

articles.title: Letters — Your Voice — for November 8
articles.summary: There are no unprecedented climate events. The oceans are not rising at an alarming rate. The Earth is not going to end in 12 years. Robert Block of Captain Cook wrote about Big Island food security on Oct. 29. John Daggett is from Portland, Ore.

articles.title: Huey Perry: Bill Gates changes his mind on climate change, unfortunately (Opinion)
articles.summary: Bill Gates declared humanity would survive climate change and 'continue to thrive'. I had just written a column that said exactly the opposite. My column warned that the Earth is warming faster than predicted and that millions of lives could be lost within the next 25 years if the trend continues.

articles.title: COP30 climate summit hears from countries suffering global warming harms
articles.summary: COP30 climate summit hears from countries suffering global warming harms. There are growing calls for developed nations that produce the most greenhouse gas emissions to take more responsibility for their climate change.       .   "There are growing concerns that developed nations produce more greenhouse gases than others.

articles.title: October heat breaks records across Taiwan
articles.summary: Taiwan saw record October heat at 11 lowland stations. October's average temperature reached 27.4 C, surpassing the 30-year climatological average of 25.2 C. Long-term climate trends show a steady increase in average, maximum, and minimum temperatures across Taiwan.

articles.title: Climate analysts in the US are observing a shift in how activists mobilise
articles.author: CNA
articles.summary: Climate analysts in the US say they're seeing a shift in how activists activate. They're seeing fewer mass demonstrations, more localised, targeted events and a pivot away from moral arguments to more lifestyle and bread and butter issues. Mitch McCann filed this report for CNA from New York.

articles.title: Climate risk is now economic risk and India must insure against it
articles.author: ET CONTRIBUTORS
articles.summary: This year's monsoon rains have been erratic and destructive. Monsoon has claimed over 1,500 lives, disrupted crops and caused estimated losses exceeding ₹24,000 crore. India is taking early steps toward climate-linked and parametric insurance models.

articles.title: Leaders turn up the heat on fossil fuels at Amazon climate summit
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: World leaders will meet for a second day of climate talks in the Brazilian Amazon yesterday. The UN's annual two-week conference, COP30, starts on Monday. UN chief Antonio Guterres and a series of national leaders said on Thursday that the world will fail to keep global warming below 1.5C.

articles.title: Global ice loss accelerating, scientists warn: 'Damage still preventable-barely'
articles.author: THT Online
articles.summary: 2025 State of the Cryosphere Report urges immediate emission cuts to avert catastrophic glacier and sea-level impacts. Global ice loss is expanding at a dangerous pace, threatening billions of people worldwide, but scientists say there is still a narrow window to prevent the worst impacts if immediate and drastic emission reductions begin now.

articles.title: Whitby man asks for support after family in Jamaica devastated by Hurricane Melissa
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa devastated Lottery district in Montego Bay St James, Jamaica on Tuesday, October 28. Tamar Green's family lost everything, but they are still alive. His mother, 96-year-old grandfather, brother, and cousins are currently living in a shelter. Donations will help provide a place to sleep, food, clean drinking water and materials to rebuild their home.

articles.title: Australia Fish Riding Whale
articles.author: 리얼빅 빅데이터로 보는 부동산
articles.summary: Australia Fish Riding Whale. Remora fish swim near a humpback whale off the coast of south-east Queensland, Australia, on Sept. 3, 2025. The photo must be used within 14 days from the transmission and must be accompanied by a written report.

articles.title: BILL GATES: Three tough truths about climate
articles.author: Bill Gates
articles.summary: There is a doomsday view that climate change will be catastrophic and people will die out in a few decades. People will be able to live and thrive in most places on Earth for the foreseeable future. The Gates Foundation's top priority is health and development in poor countries. The pool of money available to help the poorest is shrinking as rich countries cut their aid budgets.

articles.title: The year 2025 is estimated to be one of the hottest in history
articles.author: Valon Osmani
articles.summary: 2025 is expected to be the second or third hottest year on record, according to the World Meteorological Organization. Global warming is mainly caused by record concentrations of greenhouse gases and the accumulation of heat in the oceans. Sea ice and glaciers are melting at an alarming rate, while extreme weather events are causing profound social and economic upheaval. WMO emphasizes the importance of early warning systems for natural hazards.

articles.title: The year 2025 is expected to be one of the hottest in history
articles.author: Nol Elshani
articles.summary: 2025 is expected to be the second or third hottest year on record, according to the World Meteorological Organization. Global warming is mainly caused by record concentrations of greenhouse gases and the accumulation of heat in the oceans. Sea ice and glaciers are melting at an alarming rate, while extreme weather events are causing profound social and economic upheaval. WMO emphasizes the importance of early warning systems for natural hazards.

articles.title: APTOPIX Climate Wetlands Community Restoration
articles.author: Spoq
articles.summary: A storm moves through a salt marsh at sunset Monday, Oct. 6, 2025, in Charleston, S.C. APTOPIX Climate Wetlands Community Restoration is working on a project to restore the salt marshes in the Charleston area.

articles.title: Fake News: The BBC Pushes Reef Scare Again
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: The Great Barrier Reef is headed for a 'grim future' and will suffer a 'rapid coral decline' by 2050. Some parts of the reef may partially recover after 2050, but only if ocean warming is sufficiently slow to allow natural adaptation to keep pace with temperature changes.

articles.title: Outgoing chief warns Norfolk Broads faces huge challenges
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: John Packman is retiring as chief executive of the Broads Authority in the coming weeks. He has been responsible for the management of Broads for a quarter of a century. Climate change and rising sea levels are the biggest challenges for his successor. Broads are surrounded by flood plains and in the lower reaches of rivers, so some land will have to be given up to be used as floodplains.

articles.title: Broads chief warns land will be lost to the water as part of radical landscape change
articles.author: Owen Sennitt
articles.summary: John Packman is retiring as chief executive of the Broads Authority in the coming weeks. He has been responsible for the management of Broads for a quarter of a century. Climate change and rising sea levels are the biggest challenges for his successor. Broads are surrounded by flood plains and in the lower reaches of rivers, so some land will have to be given up to be used as floodplains.

articles.title: BEN SHAPIRO: Bill Gates gets mugged by reality
articles.author: Goshen News
articles.summary: Microsoft founder Bill Gates has changed his mind about climate change. For decades, Gates poured billions of dollars into climate change research. He is one of the richest people to ever walk the planet and is no longer a supporter of climate change initiatives.

articles.title: BEN SHAPIRO: Bill Gates gets mugged by reality
articles.author: Ben Shapiro
articles.summary: Microsoft founder Bill Gates has changed his mind about climate change. He no longer believes in the 'doomsday' predictions of the extreme global warming prophets. He has invested billions of dollars into the climate-industrial complex for the last several decades. He is no longer convinced that we need to stop using fossil fuels and cars.

articles.title: Ten incredibly rare birds spotted in the UK this week, and where they were last seen
articles.author: Education
articles.summary: There have been many rare bird sightings in the UK in the last week. Bonaparte's gulls, a killdeer, dusky warblers, black-faced buntings, cackling geese and a bird which impales its prey are among them.

articles.title: Global Climate Summit in the Amazon: What Are the Central Axes to Be Discussed at Cop30 in Brazil
articles.summary: At the climate summit in Belem, Brazil, officials from countries most vulnerable to the effects of climate change appealed for support. They described the natural disasters plaguing their countries, including floods, hurricanes, and rising sea levels. Representatives discussed a new initiative to protect the rainforest.

articles.title: Caribbean Currents: Devastated Jamaican communities need help
articles.author: Matias Delacroix
articles.summary: Tina J of Black River in the parish of St. Elizabeth is one of the victims of Hurricane Melissa. Many people have been left homeless without shelter, food or clothing, and without basic human needs. Tina J is asking for help now.

articles.title: Temperature to dip to near freezing overnight Monday
articles.author: Michael Hall
articles.summary: A cold front will push through the Golden Isles on Sunday and bring record-setting temperatures for a couple of days.       in Golden Isles, it's about to get cold, with the potential for record-breaking temperatures. It's going to be very cold.

articles.title: Researcher sees 'a lot of backsliding on climate commitments' since 2015 Paris conference
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: This year marks the 10th anniversary of the Paris Agreement. At that time, the countries of the world agreed that global warming should be kept well. The agreement was signed in Paris in November of 2009.       .   for confidential support call the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline on 1-800-273-8255.

articles.title: Hotter than usual weather expected to continue through early week across Israel
articles.summary: No significant change in temperatures is expected on Saturday, especially in the mountains and inland areas. Unseasonably warm weather is continuing in most parts of the country, especially the mountains, and no significant change is expected in the weather is expected.

articles.title: 30 years of COP summits: Are we still where we started in 1995?
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: World leaders are preparing to gather in Brazil for COP30 and plan climate actions. Global greenhouse-gas emissions are 34 percent higher today than they were when the first COP was held in 1995. Oil, coal, and gas are the main culprits behind the damaging emissions. The world invested a record USD 2.2 trillion in clean energy in 2024, surpassing USD 1 trillion in fossil-fuel investment for the first time. India's green transition is crucial for its development push and its role in the global fight against climate change.

articles.title: Africa at COP30: Hard-hit continent demands world put words into action
articles.author: WDN
articles.summary: Africa is heading to the 30th UN Climate Change Conference (COP30) in Belem, Brazil. The continent is calling for concrete action, including real financing, a fair transition and special recognition. Africa's climate adaptation needs are estimated at $70 billion a year, yet the continent received only $14.8 billion in 2023.

articles.title: Indian way best for climate crisis
articles.author: Statesman News Service
articles.summary: The global temperature is increasing at a rate of about 0.2 degrees Celsius per decade. The dominant discourse that has driven the global climate agenda has been the western worldview which sees nature as a commodity. The only philosophical approach that can offer a more balanced view is the ancient Bharatiya Approach. India has pursued an ambitious and proactive climate agenda.

articles.title: Deaths soar as climate crisis takes a steep health toll
articles.author: Siago Cece
articles.summary: WHO has warned of the growing health impacts of climate change. 12 out of 20 key indicators tracking climate-related health threats have hit record highs globally. Heat-related deaths have risen sharply, with mortality rates increasing by 23 per cent since the 1990s. Extreme weather events such as droughts and wildfires have worsened food insecurity, leaving 124 million more people facing moderate or severe hunger in 2023 alone.

articles.title: World Meteorological Organization: 2025 to Record Unprecedented Heat
articles.summary: The World Meteorological Organization (WMO) has warned that 2025 will be among the hottest years on record. The warning coincided with the COP30 climate summit in Brazil, where world leaders are meeting to address the accelerating effects of climate change. The last three years registered the highest temperatures ever recorded.

articles.title: COP-30 and the climate justice imperative
articles.author: Nalinikanta Dhar
articles.summary: The 30th Conference of Parties (COP-30) on climate change will be held from November 10 to 21 in Belém, Brazil. It will bring together nearly 40,000 delegates from about 200 countries. Europe and North America have been responsible for nearly 47% of cumulative global carbon emissions. Developing nations, with limited capital, technology, and infrastructure, have borne the greatest burden of climate disruption despite contributing little to the problem. Wealthy nations cannot pollute for profit while the world's poor bear the consequences.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning about dangerous 'tipping point' with major consequences: 'The new norm'
articles.author: Megan Lewis
articles.summary: Arctic warming is happening three times faster than the global average. There has been a dramatic rise in extreme occurrences in the Arctic since 2000. Scientists emphasize that understanding the Arctic's new climate state is crucial for preparing for the future. Slowing global warming means cutting polluting gases worldwide.

articles.title: COP30 — Time to stump up the cash
articles.author: Business Line
articles.summary: The upcoming climate summit is taking place in Paris. It will be the first of its kind in the world.    "This summit in Paris will take place on November 11th and will focus on climate change issues. It is expected to last about two hours.

articles.title: Australia Fish Riding Whale
articles.author: Beaumont Enterprise
articles.summary: Remora fish will ride a humpback whale off the coast of south-east Queensland, Australia, on June 15, 2024, according to the Whales and Climate Program's website. The video was made from a video made from video remora fish riding humpback whales.

articles.title: Climate Crossroads: Confusion causing increased climate anxiety
articles.author: William Lytle-Mcghee
articles.summary: There is a lot of confusion about the state of the climate change issue. Donald Trump, Bill Gates, Antonio Guterres, Michael Mann and Danielle Smith are giving mixed messages on the issue. The confusion is causing an increasing amount of climate anxiety among young people.

articles.title: ‘Climate change is driven by human need and human greed': Yale historian Sunil Amrith on his book and all things climate change
articles.author: Sunil Amrith
articles.summary: Sunil Amrith's new book, The Burning Earth, is about the connection between global warming and environmental shifts over the last 500 years. The quest to feed ourselves has always been the most fundamental way in which human activity has transformed the planet. The pursuit of luxuries by a small elite has had a disproportionate role in driving environmental harm. Post-colonial regimes and their scientists were more ambitious than their colonial forebears.

articles.title: UN warns, extreme heat will become more frequent, intense and widespread
articles.author: Independent Australia
articles.summary: The hottest year on record globally was in 2024. Bangladesh was the worst-hit country, with 33 million people affected. Children, the elderly and outdoor low-wage earners in poor and densely populated urban areas suffered the most, as they had less access to cooling systems or to water supplies and adequate healthcare. Global warming can influence weather, precipitation and glacial behaviour across Central and South Asia. By 2060, Iran, Mongolia, Myanmar, Turkey and Uzbekistan could lose more than 70% of their glacier mass.

articles.title: Futures File: UN secretary UN-happy with climate efforts
articles.author: The Indiana Times
articles.summary: Scientists have warned that the nations of the world have so far failed to limit the rise in temperature to 1.5 degrees Celsius. This threshold temperature is said to risk extreme heating and irreversible consequences, according to the scientists. The world needs to act now to limit temperature rise to this threshold temperature.

articles.title: POLL! What Does the Temperature Have to Be Outside to Warrant a Fire Inside?
articles.summary: Humboldt's annual temperature drop is here. The last remnants of summer have dissipated. How low does the temperature need to be outside for a rational person to want to light a fire inside their home? Vote below. Poll closes on Monday at 4:20 pm.

articles.title: Hurricane Melissa claims 75 lives across Caribbean nations
articles.author: Dimsum Daily Newsroom
articles.summary: Hurricane Melissa has killed 75 people and displaced more than 770,000 people in Cuba, Haiti and Jamaica. The UN and its humanitarian partners have mobilised comprehensive support operations across all three affected nations. In Jamaica, the Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs has reinforced its staffing presence to assist government-led relief efforts.

articles.title: Scientists issue warning after uncovering factor driving natural phenomenon: 'May face an increased risk'
articles.author: Gabriel Holton
articles.summary: Scientists issue warning after uncovering factor driving natural phenomenon: East Antarctica may face an increased risk of warming, while West Antarctica could experience even more dramatic temperature rises. Long-term warming amplifies their power and frequency, making communities more vulnerable overall. Supporting clean energy development, reducing reliance on dirty fossil fuels, and backing international research partnerships can help limit the chain reactions.

articles.title: Zimbabwe: Climate Finance Neglects Workers and Communities, Warns ActionAid Ahead of COP30
articles.author: All Africa
articles.summary: Less than 3% of global climate finance is supporting approaches that protect workers, women and communities during the shift to greener economies, according to ActionAid's new report.       .   "Less than three per cent of global Climate Finance is supporting approach that protects workers and women".
